awd_titl_txt: RUI: Quantum Kinetics of Neutrinos: a window on nuclear and particle astrophysics in the Early Universe and Compact Objects
awd_abstract_narration:
Neutrinos are particles that travel through the universe at the speed of light, but very rarely interact with matter.  Trillions of neutrinos pass through our bodies every second without leaving a trace.  In hot and dense astrophysical environments, prodigious numbers of neutrinos significantly impact each other and their environment.  Here, neutrinos play an important role in energy transport, affecting the dynamics of these environments, and in converting protons to neutrons and vice-versa, affecting the synthesis of elements. Therefore, understanding how neutrinos evolve is essential to addressing intriguing topics in astrophysics, including understanding the origins of the elements and using precise observations to elucidate fundamental physics.  The PI will train undergraduate researchers, engaging them in various skills that are valuable across a range of 21st century careers.  They will simulate numerically the evolution of neutrinos in astrophysical environments and their concomitant effect on their environment. This evolution is complicated by the quantum mechanical nature of particles, interactions of neutrinos with other neutrinos, and the high rate at which they collide.  In addition to mentoring undergraduate researchers, the PI will broaden the impact of this project by enhancing outreach projects run by the Society of Physics Students chapter at the University of San Diego. 

This project will study the evolution of neutrinos in hot and dense astrophysical environments where prodigious fluxes of neutrinos affect the dynamics of their environment.  Here, neutrino evolution is complicated by their nonlinear evolution due to neutrino-neutrino interactions, their coherent, quantum mechanical behavior, and their high scattering rates (kinetics) that influence the aforementioned effects.  In environments such as the early universe, within the first second after the Big Bang, and the explosive end of stars' lives, this nonlinear quantum kinetic behavior plays an important role because neutrinos transport energy over large length scales and govern the interconversion between protons and neutrons.  These effects need to be self-consistently understood in order to better understand the synthesis of the elements and to perform the high-precision calculations needed to complement high-precision cosmological observations that look to use the universe as a laboratory to study fundamental physics.  The quantum kinetic equations for neutrino evolution in astrophysical environments are known.  The goal of this project is to solve these equations in astrophysical environments toward toward gaining a broader understanding of the nonlinear quantum kinetic evolution of neutrino states and to elucidate the feedback of this evolution on the astrophysical environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Neutrinos -- Nature's stealthy and shape-shifting particles -- play an essential role in the evolution of hot and dense astrophysical environments. By contrast, in our everyday lives, trillions of neutrinos from the sun pass through our bodies every second, but because they can only affect other particles through the weak nuclear interaction, they have no effect. While this non-effect is beneficial to our bodies, it limits the depth to which the terrestrial laboratory can directly probe the neutrino sector. In this project, we investigated different scenarios in the early universe, seconds after the Big Bang where neutrinos play an important role in dynamics and nucleosynthesis.  

Here, in the early universe, the coupling between neutrino astrophysics and nuclear astrophysics can be seen hand-in-hand. One connection is through the process of Big Bang Nucleosynthesis (BBN), where the first nuclei formed minutes after the Big Bang. During BBN, electron neutrinos and anti-neutrinos mediate the relative numbers of neutrons and protons in the hot, dense plasma of the early universe. The expansion of the universe is, in part, dependent on the energy density of all neutrino and anti-neutrino flavors. Big Bang Nucleosynthesis provides the opportunity to probe the neutrino sector in ways that cannot be probed in the terrestrial laboratory. Furthermore, the next generation of astrophysical observatories will provide the opportunity for high-precision measurements that allows BBN to probe fundamental physics. 

Two publications on the BBN epoch were produced from this project.  The first explored equilibrium processes during the BBN epoch and by directly calculating reaction rates, we found that the equilibrium approximations used in BBN reaction networks perform an accurate and computationally speedy job of modeling these processes. This is an important check to assure that BBN can play a valuable role in using the early universe to probe fundamental physics.  

In the other paper, we leveraged the sensitivity of the BBN epoch to neutrino physics in order to constrain particle physics models beyond the Standard Model. These models posit the existence of never before seen particles that decay fractions of a second after they are born in the hot Big Bang. While these possibilities may seem fleeting, their impact can be imprinted on BBN yields formed minutes later and on the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) formed after 400,000 years. We found that there may be interesting scenarios that could have observational signatures in future CMB observations and that these may distinguished by differing BBN abundance yields. This remains a project for future examination, and may provide an interesting resolution to the lithium problem, the current discrepancy between theoretical calculation of BBN yields of lithium and observations.  

This project was completed at the University of San Diego, a primarily undergraduate institution and overall supported the work of 15 undergraduate student researchers. Straddling the academic disruptions of the COVID-19 pandemic, work on this project accentuates the pedagogical value of experiential learning driven by frontier research in the physics curriculum.  Undergraduate student researchers participating in this project have presented their work at national conferences with 7 posters and 4 contributed talks on the topics described above as well as projects in dark matter production and quantum evolution of neutrinos in the early universe. These have seeded projects for future work of undergraduate student researchers at the University of San Diego.
